lexUnit.name: taste.n
lexUnit.definition: COD: the sensation of flavour perceived in the mouth on contact with a substance.

sentence.text: Hazel sat nibbling and biting , the rich , full taste of the cultivated roots filling him with a wave of pleasure .
` Would it not be better if you were asking us such questions with a beer in front of yourself and the taste of it warming your throat ?
Many people dislike the taste of bran and find it hard to swallow .
My brother just dislikes the taste of meat and is faintly surprised that other people do not .
Each salmon remembers the precise taste of the waters in which it hatched , a flavour derived from the mix of minerals in its mud and the plants and animals that live in it .
It was the taste of death in his mouth that preoccupied him .
Something was needed to take away the taste of the coffee and the interview with the AC .
` Ja " , he whispered , as she caressed his corded neck with her open mouth , overwhelmed by the scent and taste of his heated , sweat-dampened skin .
The dancing bee also regurgitates food to the recruits to illustrate its taste .
He had only kissed her a few times before , yet his taste was as familiar as the beat of his heart beneath her hand as she clutched his shirt .
Its raspberry taste may be derived from a suitable combination of flavourings added to the food .
Three of the sliced loaves stood out among the rest , which were thin-looking with a raw dough taste and vinegary or salty aromas .
The main symptom is heartburn -- a sharp pain behind the breastbone , caused by acidic stomach juices irritating the gullet , and sometimes a bitter taste in the mouth .
It must have a taste to it .
It was at the open window when Anna woke next morning , and in her mouth , a horrible taste like being very ill .
` These are dishes we have adapted over the years to be vegan but are also the authentic tastes of , chiefly , Malaysia but Vietnam , Cambodia and Singapore as well , " Rex said .
